Introduction
Praise be to Allah, and peace and blessings be upon the Messenger of Allah, and upon his family and companions until the Day of Judgment. To proceed:
Islam is the religion that Allah Almighty chose for His servants, since He created the first creation, Adam, peace be upon him. Allah Almighty says: {Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam} (1). And He also says: {And whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him} (2). He made for this religion one central axis until the Day of Resurrection, which is His Oneness (Tawhid), Glory be to Him and Exalted is He. This is the axis to which the prophets and messengers called their peoples and followers. He, the Exalted, says: {And We certainly sent into every nation a messenger, [saying], "Worship Allah and avoid Taghut"} (3). And He says: {And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me} (4).

Thus, it came carrying ease and breadth in its rulings and legislations. This is a great favor from Allah Almighty to this nation. This was not a casual matter, but rather for a wisdom known to Allah, intended for His servants in line with their nature (Fitrah) and to help them in performing their obediences and worships, and consequently achieving their interests in all their affairs. Every ruling or legislation carries with it an interest for people in their selves, wealth, children, and others. If we want to delve into the depths of the principle of facilitation and tolerance in the religion of Allah Almighty, we will find ourselves before a vast sea of evidence, texts, and events that affirm this principle and urge Muslims to adopt and follow it. text:
The Concept of Ease
'Yusr' (Ease) linguistically: The opposite of hardship ('Usr'). From it is "Religion is 'yusr' (easy)" meaning easy, tolerant, with little strictness (1).
As for terminologically: It is the application of legal rulings in a moderate manner as they came in the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him, without strictness that prohibits the lawful, nor laxity that permits the forbidden.
Included under this name are tolerance (Samahah), breadth (Sa'ah), removal of hardship (Raf' al-Haraj), and other terms that carry the same meaning.
We will discuss ease and tolerance in light of the following elements:

text:
First - The Islamic Religion is Based on Ease and Tolerance
The Islamic religion in its entirety is based on ease and the removal of hardship, starting from Creed (Aqeedah) and ending with the smallest matters of rulings and worships, in a way that aligns with human nature and is accepted by the human soul without affectation or stubbornness. This is what Allah Almighty pointed to in many places in His Noble Book, including His saying: {and has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty} (1), and His saying: {Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship} (2), and His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {Allah wants to lighten for you [your difficulties]; and mankind was created weak} (3).
Following these noble verses, the Prophetic Sunnah came with many hadiths carrying meanings of ease in matters of religion and lack of extremism and strictness in worship and obedience. The Prophet, peace be upon him, indicated that one of the most important features distinguishing the message of Islam from previous divine messages is tolerance and ease, as in his saying, peace be upon him: «Religion is very easy and whoever overburdens himself in his religion will not be able to continue in that way. So you should not be extremists, but try to be near to perfection and receive the good tidings that you will be rewarded; and gain strength by worshipping in the mornings, the afternoons, and during the last hours of the nights» (4).

text: Anyone contemplating the Prophetic biography (Seerah) will find that the behavior of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his dealings with his companions are built on the methodology of facilitation and tolerance. The evidence is more than can be counted, but we suffice with narrating an incident that happened to one of the companions who came to the Messenger, peace be upon him, wanting a way out for it while he was a poor companion not owning his daily sustenance. It dispenses with mentioning all the embarrassments that used to happen to the companions. Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, says: «While we were sitting with the Prophet (peace be upon him), a man came and said, "O Allah's Messenger! I have been ruined." Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) asked, "What is the matter with you?" He replied "I had sexual intercourse with my wife while I was fasting." Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) asked, "Can you afford to manumit a slave?" He replied in the negative. Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) asked, "Can you fast for two successive months?" He replied in the negative. The Prophet (peace be upon him) asked, "Can you afford to feed sixty poor persons?" He replied in the negative. The Prophet (peace be upon him) kept silent (for a while) and while we were in that state, a big basket full of dates was brought to the Prophet (peace be upon him). He asked, "Where is the questioner?" He replied, "I (am here)." The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "Take this and give it in charity." The man said, "Am I to give it to one who is poorer than I, O Allah's Messenger? By Allah, there is no poorer family between its two labbahs (i.e., the two lava plains of Medina) than mine." The Prophet (peace be upon him) smiled till his canine teeth became visible and then said, "Feed your family with it."» (1).

1 - Concession (Rukhsa)
'Rukhsa' in language: Facilitation and easing, or ease and facility. 'Rukhs' is the opposite of high cost ('Ghala'). Someone 'yatarakh-khas' in a matter if he does not investigate thoroughly. It is transitive with Hamza and doubling (1).
As for terminologically, Al-Baydawi defined it as: "The ruling established contrary to the evidence due to an excuse" (2).
Rukhsa is a great rule among the rules of this religion as it includes all matters and aspects of religion in Creed, Worship, Transactions, Penalties, and others. It is a grant and charity from Allah Almighty to His servants, as the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: «It is a charity which Allah has bestowed upon you, so accept His charity» (3). Rukhsa can be described as one of the most important landmarks of ease in this religion, and that Allah Almighty only permitted it to lighten the burden of some obligations for His servants, and excuse them from what they cannot bear. Therefore, it is recommended to take this grant and act upon it in places of permissibility. The Prophet, peace be upon him, says: «Allah loves that His concessions be taken as He dislikes that His disobedience be committed» (4). 2 - The Original State of Things is Permissibility
One of the most important pillars upon which the methodology of facilitation in Islam is based is that the origin in things is lawfulness and permissibility, not prevention and prohibition. Everything created in this universe is subjected for humans and prepared for their enjoyment, as long as there is no explicit prohibition. Allah Almighty says: {And He has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth - all from Him} (1). Since the Lawgiver has clarified that, no one has the right to forbid this permissible thing, for by doing so he enters the scope of extremism and obstinacy which is forbidden. For this reason, the divine warning came against forbidding permissible matters or permitting the forbidden. Such questioning was a cause for taking people out of the true religion and bringing Allah's wrath upon them, as happened to some previous nations. Allah Almighty says: {O you who have believed, do not ask about things which, if they are shown to you, will distress you. But if you ask about them while the Qur'an is being revealed, they will be shown to you. Allah has pardoned that which is past; and Allah is Forgiving and Forbearing} {A people asked about them before you; then they became therein disbelievers} (2).

3 - Mistake, Forgetfulness, and Compulsion
The tolerance of Islam appears in its compatibility with the sound human nature created within man. Part of this nature is the mistake that man falls into in most of his conditions unintentionally, as well as the forgetfulness that befalls him. This is what Allah Almighty mentioned on the tongue of the believers who said: {Our Lord, do not impose blame upon us if we have forgotten or erred}. Allah Almighty said: "I have done so" (1).
As for compulsion, it is a matter beyond human will. Not every human can bear the harm, damage, or threat of killing or cutting of a limb etc. that he might be exposed to. In that case, the Lawgiver permitted him to concede some of his religious concepts to escape the state he is suffering and the torture befalling him, as happened to Ammar bin Yasir, may Allah be pleased with them both, when he mentioned the gods of Quraish with good and spoke ill of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, under the pressure of torture, and his parents were killed before his eyes. He complained about that to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, so the Messenger, peace be upon him, said to him: «(How do you find your heart?), he said: At peace with faith. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: (If they return, then return)» (2).

4 - Prohibition of Extremism in Religion
The religion of Allah Almighty carries happiness and justice for people in its application, not misery and torment. The person who takes this religion as Allah Almighty wanted, with moderation, understanding, and awareness, attains happiness and salvation in this world and the Hereafter. As for the one who goes to extremes in it and is strict where strictness is not placed, and prohibits the lawful and permissible, he attains misery and torment in this world and the Hereafter. Our Lord, Mighty and Majestic, refers to this meaning at the beginning of Surah Taha saying: {Ta, Ha.} {We have not sent down to you the Qur'an that you be distressed} (1).
The Prophet, peace be upon him, says: «Ruined are those who indulge in hair-splitting (extremism)» he said it three times (2). The hair-splitters (Mutanatti'un), as interpreted by Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him: Those who go too deep and are strict in places where strictness is not appropriate (3).

text: The acceptance of obedience is not linked to the extent of fatigue and toil, because Allah Almighty does not like to be obeyed by other than what He revealed to His servants. He who worships Allah night and day in a manner contrary to the methodology of Allah Almighty, his worship is not accepted no matter how much he tires and exhausts himself. Allah Almighty is in no need of the servants' deeds, but He - Exalted is His affair - rejoices when He sees His servants upon His upright religion. The Mother of Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, says: «The Prophet (peace be upon him) came in when a woman was sitting with me. He said, "Who is this?" I said, "She is so-and-so," and I mentioned her (excessive) prayers. He said, "Do not do that! You should do only that which you can do, for by Allah, Allah does not get tired (of giving reward) but you get tired," and the most beloved religion (deeds) to him was that in which its doer persists» (1). Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, says: «The Prophet (peace be upon him) entered the mosque and saw a rope hanging between two pillars. He said, "What is this rope?" The people said, "This rope is for Zainab who, when she feels tired, holds it (to keep standing for the prayer.)" The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "Don't use it. Remove the rope. You should pray as long as you feel active, and when you get tired, sit down"» (2).

5 - Repentance (Tawbah)
Repentance is one of the solid foundations upon which the methodology of facilitation in Islam rests. It is a cause for the believer's steadfastness and remaining upon the religion of Allah Almighty, as it removes from his shoulders the worries of sins and the burdens of violations, and pushes him to always work towards the better. Allah Almighty says: {Say, "O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful."} (1). Repentance is a cause for Allah's love for the human when he turns back to Him after disobeying Him, and regrets his action: {Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves} (2). This meaning is supported by his saying, peace be upon him: «Allah is more pleased with the repentance of His servant than anyone of you is with finding his lost animal» (3).

This is a major sin, a corrupt belief, and thinking ill of Allah, Exalted is His affair. It is one of Satan's doors to prevent him from returning to his Lord again and doing good deeds. The Prophet, peace be upon him, says: «By Him in Whose Hand is my life, if you were not to commit sin, Allah would simply eliminate you and would substitute you with a people who would commit sin and ask forgiveness from Allah, and He would forgive them» (1). And he, peace be upon him, says: «Every son of Adam sins, and the best of the sinners are the repentant» (2). From the ease, breadth, and mercy of this religion is that Allah Almighty made good deeds expiations for the sins of the sons of Adam, due to His saying: {Except for those who repent, believe and do righteous work. For them Allah will replace their evil deeds with good. And ever is Allah Forgiving and Merciful} (3). And his saying, peace be upon him, to Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him: «Fear Allah wherever you are, follow a bad deed with a good deed and it will wipe it out, and behave well towards the people» (4).

Many hadiths have been reported clarifying deeds that expiate bad deeds and reduce them, and raise ranks and increase status with Allah Almighty. We mention some of them:
a - Ablution (Wudu), for it expiates the Muslim's sins and misdeeds as long as major sins are avoided, due to his saying, peace be upon him: «He who performed ablution well, his sins would come out from his body, even coming out from under his nails» (1).
b - The five daily prayers and Friday prayer to the next Friday prayer, as well as fasting Ramadan; all of them expiate the sins of the son of Adam and raise his ranks and status with Allah Almighty. The Prophet, peace be upon him, says: «The five daily (prayers) and the Friday (prayer) to the Friday (prayer) and Ramadan to Ramadan are expiations for what is between them if major sins are avoided» (2). He said, 'It expiates the sins of the previous year and of the coming year.' He was asked about fasting on the day of Ashura. He said, 'It expiates the sins of the previous year'» (3).
c - Every trial and calamity a Muslim is afflicted with is an expiation for him, due to his saying, peace be upon him: «No fatigue, nor disease, nor sorrow, nor sadness, nor hurt, nor distress befalls a Muslim, even if it were the prick he receives from a thorn, but that Allah expiates some of his sins for that» (4).

1 - In Creed (Aqeedah)
The Islamic religion is distinguished from other religions and creeds by the clarity of its creed and the ease of faith in Allah Almighty. It commanded people to worship Allah alone, that He is the One God who neither begot nor was born, and there is none co-equal or comparable to Him. In His hand is the dominion of the heavens and the earth, there is no deity worthy of worship except Him, and there is no mediation between servants and their Creator, nor partners with Him. The Islamic creed contains no puzzles known only to a group of rabbis and monks, nor does it have ambiguity and obscurity as in other creeds like splitting the One into three. It does not insult the human mind by worshipping stones, persons, and animals as in Buddhism and others. Rather, it is a creed of utmost ease and tolerance, understood by the Bedouin living in the desert when he said: The droppings indicate the camel, and the footprint indicates walking. So a dark night, and a sky with constellations, do they not indicate the One, the Subduer? Or as he said.

2 - In Acts of Worship (Ibadat)
The principle of ease and tolerance appears clearly in acts of worship more than any other aspect of religion, as they are apparent behavior. All acts of worship are based on this principle which Allah Almighty bestowed upon this nation over other nations, both obligatory and voluntary ones. The Prophet, peace be upon him, says: «Do only that which you can do, for by Allah, Allah does not get tired (of giving reward) but you get tired» (1). We can point out some of these manifestations in the following acts of worship:
a - In Purification (Taharah):

text: The principle of ease and tolerance appears clearly in purification because it is the gateway to acts of worship. Ease in it is necessary because a Muslim performs ablution five times a day and night, and bathes from sexual impurity (Janabah) as well, and is exposed to some impurities here and there. Strictness in purification puts him in distress and embarrassment and makes his self weary of worship itself, let alone purification, as is the case with many who suffer from obsessive-compulsive disorder (Waswasah) during ablution, purification, or when some impurities fall on clothes, etc. This is what the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade. It is part of the tolerance and ease of this religion, and a favor from Allah Almighty to His servants so they rush towards obedience and performing worships in the required manner. He, peace be upon him, says regarding the purity of water: «Water is not made impure by anything except what overcomes its smell, taste, and color» (1). And he, peace be upon him, says about sea water: «Its water is purifying and its dead (animals) are lawful» (2). The ease of this religion in purification is evident from the story of the Bedouin who urinated in the mosque, so the people got up to beat him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to them: «Leave him and pour a bucket or a tumbler of water over his urine, for you have been sent to make things easy and not to make them difficult» (3).

Confirmation of this matter came in the Prophetic Sunnah in his saying, peace be upon him: «I have been given five things which were not given to anyone else before me: I have been helped by terror (in the hearts of enemies) spanning the distance of a month's journey. c - In Prayer (Salah): Some forms of facilitation in prayer can be clarified through the following points:
- Its obligation is five times a day and night, so it does not take a long time, nor does it distract a person from performing his daily work. Rather, they are meetings with Allah Almighty in which the believer renews the covenant with his Lord for obedience, uprightness, and righteousness. Fifty prayers were initially obligated during the Ascension (Mi'raj) of the Prophet, peace be upon him, then they became five prayers with the reward of fifty prayers, and in that is tolerance and mercy.

- Legitimacy of combining and shortening prayers during travel, rain, or illness, due to the circumstances a person experiences in these cases such as lack of water, cold, fear of the road, or increased illness. Therefore, Islam made prayer in a different form suitable for these circumstances, permitting him to combine and shorten, where four-unit prayers are shortened to two units only. From Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: «The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) stayed in Tabuk for twenty days shortening the prayer» (1).

This prayer is called the Fear Prayer. He Almighty said: {And when you travel throughout the land, there is no blame upon you for shortening the prayer, [especially] if you fear that those who disbelieve may disrupt [or attack] you. Indeed, the disbelievers are ever to you a clear enemy} (2). Then the following verse mentioned how to perform this prayer in two batches.

- Lightening the prayer and not elongating it, because congregational prayer gathers the young, the old, and the sick, so this should be considered. This is what the Messenger, peace be upon him, warned his companions about. Jabir bin Abdullah Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, says: «A man came with two camels used for watering and the night had fallen. He found Mu'adh praying so he made his camel kneel and joined Mu'adh, but the latter recited Surah Al-Baqarah or Surah An-Nisa, so the man left the prayer and went away. When he learned that Mu'adh had criticized him, he went to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and complained against Mu'adh. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "O Mu'adh! Are you putting the people to trial?" Thrice. "It would have been better if you had recited 'Sabbih Isma Rabbika-l-A'la' (87), Wash-Shamsi wadh-uhaha (91), or Wal-Laili idha yaghsha (92), for the old, the weak and the needy pray behind you."» (1). The Prophet, peace be upon him, says: «I stand for prayer intending to prolong it, but on hearing the cries of a child, I shorten it, as I dislike to trouble his mother» (2).

This is ease and kindness towards women, as they suffer pain and blood during menstruation and postpartum periods, making prayer difficult, and the period may be long making make-up difficult. So divine mercy came to the woman with this facilitation, and she was not asked to make up those missed prayers.

All this ease and tolerance came in the second pillar of Islam after the two testimonies, which is Prayer, the greatest practical deed. In this is a great witness and clear proof of the ease and tolerance of this religion in worship.
d - In Zakat:
The manifestations of ease and facilitation in performing the obligation of Zakat are evident through the following matters:
- It did not apply to all properties, real estate, and funds, but was limited to certain categories such as: grazing livestock, gold and silver (currency), crops, and trade goods.
- Then it is stipulated in the categories where Zakat is obligatory that they reach the Nisab (minimum amount). For silver it is two hundred dirhams, for gold twenty mithqals, for grazing camels five, for cows thirty, for sheep forty, and for grains, crops, and fruits five Awsuq. Many hadiths have clarified this.
- Also from the ease of Islam in performing this obligation is that it made paying Zakat only once a year, after a lunar year passes over it.
- From that is that the amount of money obligated to be paid for Zakat is very small relative to the money on which Zakat is obligatory, such that it does not affect it much, nor is its owner affected by that.

Such conditions and descriptions for Zakat make the owner of wealth rush to pay the Zakat of his wealth willingly, without boredom, weariness, or heaviness.
e - In Fasting:
Some forms of facilitation in the obligation of fasting can be listed by clarifying the following points:
- That fasting was not obligated except in one month of the year, which is the month of Ramadan, due to His saying: {[Fasting for] a limited number of days} (2). This is facilitation and breadth in the time of this obligation; the believer can perform it acceptably without hardship or difficulty.
- That the time of fasting is from dawn to sunset, and it is not permissible to exceed this time. For this reason, continuous fasting (Wisal), which is connecting the fast of two or three consecutive days, was forbidden due to the hardship and distress on the soul and danger to the human it entails. The Prophet, peace be upon him, says: «Do not practice Al-Wisal» (3) meaning in fasting.

4 - In Transactions:
Ease in Islam was not limited to Creed (Aqidah) and Worship (Ibadah) but extended to transactions which occupy a wide area of practical human life. Trade, industry, agriculture, education, and others all fall under the umbrella of transactions. People are more prone to sins and offenses in transactions because their driving force is money, and the extent of money's influence on the human soul, nature, and behavior is well known. Therefore, Quranic and Prophetic texts followed one another in adopting ease and tolerance in transactions. He, peace and blessings be upon him, says: «May Allah have mercy on a man who is easy when he sells, when he buys, and when he demands his rights» (1). He also says: «Whoever cancels the sale of a Muslim, Allah will cancel his slip on the Day of Resurrection» (2). Some forms of ease in transactions can be clarified through the following points:

A - In sales, Islam allowed the buyers and sellers the option (Khiyar) in a number of situations, such as when they are in the session of the sale, to remove the embarrassment that one of them might fall into, because great harm might occur if this contract is concluded. He, peace and blessings be upon him, says: «When two men conduct a sale, each one of them has the option as long as they have not separated and are together; or one of them gives the other the option, and if they agree on that, the sale becomes binding. And if they separate after conducting the sale and neither of them cancels the sale, the sale becomes binding» (1).
B - Furthermore, this religion prohibited usury (Riba), which involves injustice to people and exploitation of their circumstances, and is a cause for the spread of obscene poverty and wealth, and a cause for planting hatred and grudges among members of the same society. So Allah prohibited usury and permitted the good loan (Qard Hasan). Allah Almighty says: {Allah destroys interest and gives increase for charities} (2). And He, Glorified be His Praise, says: {And lend to Allah a good loan} (3).
C - This religion also prohibited hoarding food and goods and withholding them at a time when people's need for them is intense. He, peace and blessings be upon him, says: «No one hoards but a sinner» (4). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, says: «Whoever interferes in any of the prices of the Muslims to increase them against them, it is a right upon Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, to seat him in a great place of Fire on the Day of Resurrection» (5).

text: D - Ease towards the insolvent debtor: This is a great principle brought by Islam, out of mercy for his condition and appreciation for his harsh circumstances. It is a strong element of social solidarity among the members of the nation, making society a solid unit based on love, harmony, cooperation, and mutual compassion. This is a practical application of His Almighty's saying: {And if someone is in hardship, then [let there be] postponement until [a time of] ease. But if you give [from your right as] charity, then it is better for you, if you only knew} (1). This blessed principle of ease towards the insolvent debtor is missed by the contemporary world amidst this massive civilized development, and despite the existence of major international associations concerned with human affairs, freedoms, and rights. It is the commandment of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, since fourteen centuries ago to his companions and the nation after them in his saying: «Whoever is pleased that Allah saves him from the distress of the Day of Resurrection, let him relieve an insolvent person or alleviate his debt» (2). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, says in the story of a man from previous nations who used to overlook insolvent people: «There was a merchant who used to lend to people. If he saw an insolvent person, he would say to his servants: Overlook him, perhaps Allah will overlook us. So Allah overlooked him» (3).

5 - In Punishments:
Islamic Sharia is distinguished from other laws and legislations in criminal legislation and establishing appropriate punishments for people's actions that harm lives, properties, honors, and others. The Sharia has bestowed upon these punishments colors of tolerance and ease, such that the human soul accepts them in all its conditions, and even demands them if such actions occur. We can clarify this tolerance and breadth through explaining only two punishments, which are:
A - Punishment for killing a soul:
Killing a soul without right is considered one of the biggest crimes and greatest sins in the sight of Allah Almighty. Allah Almighty says: {And do not kill the soul which Allah has forbidden, except by right. This has He instructed you that you may use reason} (1). Allah - the Exalted - has made killing a single soul tantamount to killing all people, and saving a soul tantamount to saving all people. Allah Almighty says: {Because of that, We decreed upon the Children of Israel that whoever kills a soul unless for a soul or for corruption [done] in the land - it is as if he had slain mankind entirely} (2). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, says: «The demise of the world is less significant to Allah than the killing of a Muslim man» (3).

So killing a soul is a heinous act and a great crime; it must have a punishment commensurate with this offense and act. Thus, Allah's judgment was life for life, as per His Almighty's saying: {And We ordained for them therein a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a nose for a nose, an ear for an ear, a tooth for a tooth, and for wounds is legal retribution} (1). The ease and tolerance of Islam in applying punishment to the killer appear through the following points:
- No one is held accountable for the crime of another; meaning, only the killer himself is punished, and his family, relatives, and tribe have no part in his action or the application of punishment upon him, without arbitrariness or transgression. This is unlike what was in the days of ignorance (Jahiliyyah), where wars would break out, honors would be violated, and more than one man would be killed for one man, all because of a murder crime that happened to one of their members. As per His Almighty's saying: {And whoever is killed unjustly - We have given his heir authority, but let him not exceed limits in [the matter of] taking life. Indeed, he has been supported [by the law]} (2).

This was the way of the righteous predecessors from the Companions and Followers, may Allah be pleased with them. It was narrated that a man from Quraysh broke the tooth of a man from the Ansar, so he sought judgment against him from Muawiyah. The Qurashi said: 'This man knocked out my tooth.' Muawiyah said: 'Nay, we shall satisfy him.' But when the Ansari insisted, Muawiyah said: 'Deal with your companion.' The Ansari said: 'Did you hear this from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him?' He said: 'Yes, my ears heard it and my heart retained it.' Meaning he pardoned him (1).

If one is found among them who pardons the killer, even if it is a woman, the ruling is dropped, and retribution is prevented. Likewise, if among the blood guardians there is one who has not reached the age of discernment or is absent, his reaching maturity or return from absence is awaited to take his opinion. If he pardons the offender, the ruling is dropped. This might take years, and in that is wisdom; perhaps these guardians will forget their anger over their blood and the burden will lighten upon them, so pardon then becomes closer than retribution.

B - Punishment for Adultery:
The crime of adultery is one of the moral crimes that corrupt families and societies, mix lineages, and spread grudges and hatred. Therefore, this crime was among the major sins for which Allah threatened the doer with painful punishment in this world and the Hereafter. As per His Almighty's saying: {Indeed, those who like that immorality should be spread [or publicized] among those who have believed will have a painful punishment in this world and the Hereafter. And Allah knows and you do not know} (1).
The punishment for the adulterer is stoning for the married (Muhsan) and lashes for the unmarried (non-Muhsan). In this, there is ease and tolerance, by proportionate punishment with the nature of the adulterer himself. The married adulterer has committed a greater crime than the non-married adulterer; therefore, his punishment came harsher and more severe, which is stoning.

Fourth - Legal Maxims Derived from Texts Regarding Ease:
Scholars of Usul (Principles of Jurisprudence) derived some maxims from the texts concerning the tolerance and ease of Islam and made them landmarks for the science of Usul. We mention two fundamental maxims:
1 - "Hardship brings ease" (1):
The meaning of this Usuli maxim is that rulings whose application results in difficulty for the accountable person (Mukallaf) and hardship upon himself or his wealth, the Sharia has permitted him not to perform them. This legal maxim relies on many evidences from the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, which were referred to during the research (2), through clarifying the ease of Islam, its breadth, and its mercy towards servants in worship, transactions, granting licenses, and others. The hardship that permits doing the prohibited and brings ease is that which is beyond human capacity, so the human soul cannot bear it, and if a person undertakes it, he is exposed to harm and damage in the essentials of his life: self, wealth, mind, and honor. Other sub-maxims emerged from this Usuli maxim such as: "If a matter narrows, it widens," or "If a matter widens, it narrows" (3) and others.
2 - "Necessities permit prohibitions" (4):

text: The basis on which this Usuli maxim relied is His Almighty's saying: {And He has explained to you in detail what He has forbidden to you, excepting that to which you are compelled} (1). Attached to this maxim is another maxim which serves as a control and restriction for it, which is: "Necessities are estimated according to their extent" (2). Meaning that the permissible part of doing prohibited acts is according to the person's need so that the harm threatening him is negated. He should not exceed this amount, otherwise he falls into sin. Like one approaching death from thirst; he is not allowed to drink wine beyond what quenches his thirst and saves him from death. Fifth - Effects of Straying from the Methodology of Ease:
Straying from the methodology of ease has serious effects on the individual and society, including:
1 - Burdening with what is unbearable:
Any excessive strictness in applying the rulings and obligations of this religion, and any transgression of the line Allah - the Exalted - drew for His servants, will expose its owner to falling into difficulty and sin. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, clarified this to those individuals who tried to burden themselves with what they could not bear. Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, says: «A group of three men came to the houses of the wives of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, asking how the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, worshipped. When they were informed about that, they considered their worship insufficient and said: "Where are we from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, as his past and future sins have been forgiven." Then one of them said: "I will offer the prayer throughout the night forever." The other said: "I will fast throughout the year and will not break my fast." The third said: "I will keep away from women and will not marry forever." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came to them and said: "Are you the same people who said so-and-so? By Allah, I am more submissive to Allah and more afraid of Him than you; yet I fast and break my fast, I do sleep and I also marry women. So he who does not follow my Sunnah in religion, is not from me (not one of my followers)» (1).

text: Human nature and instinct cannot bear persisting in actions that contradict this nature and instinct. Sleep is an instinct and instinctual need that a human must satisfy. One whose sleep decreases cannot perform his scientific, preaching, and livelihood activities during the day. Allah - the Exalted - mentioned that it is rest and slumber for humans in more than one place in His Dear Book: {And made your sleep [a means for] rest} (1). Likewise, marriage, through which life continues and human progeny increases, is a Sunnah from which a human cannot detach. Whoever wants to abstain from marriage contradicts his nature, contributes to the destruction of life, and violates the Law of Allah - the Exalted - who mandated the principle of marriage and encouraged it in many texts from the Book and the Prophetic Sunnah. The third matter indicated by the Hadith is abstaining from eating and continuous fasting. This is also a burden on the soul and a load incompatible with human nature and instinct, which leans towards enjoying the good things Allah brought out for His servants from this earth.

To establish the principle of ease and tolerance in applying this religion, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, rushed to bring these individuals and clarify the grave error they tried to fall into. He informed them afterwards that he, peace and blessings be upon him, is the most fearful of Allah and most pious towards Him, yet he does not neglect one thing at the expense of another. He sleeps and prays, marries women, fasts and breaks his fast. This is the moderation, tolerance, and breadth brought by this great religion.
2 - Incorrect Understanding of This Religion:
Whoever ignores the methodology of ease and tolerance in Islam develops a deficiency in understanding this religion, because he did not understand this religion as Allah - the Exalted - intended for His servants, and as His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, clarified to them. This incorrect understanding, over time, extends to dive into the entirety of religious matters and fields. It does not stop at some acts of worship or specific rulings, but penetrates inside until perceptions and ideas alien to the spirit of this religion are generated in its owner, and he invites people to them, thinking he is doing good.

text: It is known that one of the most important factors for the success of Da'wah to Allah - the Exalted - is for people to become familiar with the Da'iyah (caller) and love him. This is through his understanding of the religion of Allah - the Exalted - and his method of conveying this religion in the image intended by Allah - the Exalted - and His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him. This is essential in Da'wah. If the Da'iyah is among those who adopt tolerance and breadth in conveying Islam and its principles, and does not burden people beyond their capacities as the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, used to do, then he is on good, and his Da'wah proceeds towards success and divine guidance. But if he is strict with people and burdens them with what they cannot bear, such as condemning everything even if it is permissible, and forbidding them what Allah and His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, did not forbid, then this Da'iyah is merely blowing into the wind and proceeding towards certain failure. This is because he contradicted the Law (Shar') and human natures, and ignored their instincts, desires, and needs. Mother of the Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, says clearly: «Whenever the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was given a choice between two matters, he would choose the easier of the two, as long as it was not a sin. If it was a sin, he was the furthest of people from it» (1).

text: So let the callers who mix with people and teach them their religious matters look at this great stance of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who is the role model and example for us until the Day of Judgment, to know the extent of space and breadth Allah made in His religion, and the wisdom in inviting people to it. This Bedouin coming from the desert does not know the sanctity or holiness of the mosque and thinks it is like other places, so he wanted to relieve himself in it. The Companions rose against him to beat him and scold him for this act. The Messenger of Mercy, peace and blessings be upon him, stopped them and let him finish urinating, then ordered them to pour a bucket of water over his urine to purify the place. Then he took the Bedouin gently and softly, and taught him that these places are houses of Allah established for remembrance and prayer, and it is not permissible to cause impurities in them. Then the Bedouin realized his mistake and regretted his act, and loved the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, for his wisdom and kindness towards him, compared to the Companions' behavior towards him and their attempt to beat and discipline him. He could not help but say: «O Allah, have mercy on me and Muhammad and do not have mercy on anyone else with us. Research Summary
Through this brief narrative about the tolerance and ease of Islam in applying rulings and performing acts of worship and others, we conclude with some results and recommendations which we summarize as follows:
1 - The principle of ease and tolerance is established in this religion, and it is a great objective of Islamic Sharia. No one denies it except those ignorant of the rulings of Islam and the reality of its message. It is a principle taken from many texts reported in the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the traditions of the Companions and Followers, may Allah be pleased with them.
2 - Moderation of this religion in all its aspects, in Creed, Worship, Transaction, Behavior, and others. This is in compliance with His Almighty's saying: {And thus we have made you a just community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you} (1).

3 - Straying from this methodology inherits negative effects and dangerous damages on human action and behavior in his religion and worldly life. It might take him out of the straight path to divergent paths and deviant ideas, opening the doors of innovation and novelties into this religion. Furthermore, straying from the methodology of ease has a dangerous impact on the movement of Da'wah to Allah Almighty, especially among those people who are new to this religion.
4 - Finally, establishing the principle of tolerance and ease in religion does not mean:
- Violation of the objectives of Sharia and Religion. The principle of ease should not be understood as negligence or laxity in applying the rulings of this religion and executing its commands, because this ease is not in sin or disobedience as Mother of the Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, narrated in a previous hadith: «Whenever the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was given a choice between two matters, he would choose the easier of the two, as long as it was not a sin. If it was a sin, he was the furthest of people from it» (1). This must be noted and warned against.
